`capitalize`, `startsWith`, `endsWith`, `repeat`, `trim`, `trimLeft`, `trimRight`, & `truncate`

Are there any others you all think should make the cut for 3.0?

title: merge: determine key?
body:
As I can see from documentation & code, `_.merge` `callback` argument supplied with left & right values on each merge iteration. So, I've been thinking, what if merge rule depends on a particular key? So it would be reasonably to have current merge key in callback.

For now I see the only solution in preparing both collections by recursively replacing keys with special struct that explicitly contains key in some form. But this is too complicated.

Are there any solutions or common practices for this case?

Btw, sorry, if this topic have been discussed, search says nothing to me.

title: Greater than symbols are not being escaped correctly on lodash.com/docs
body:
If you look at http://lodash.com/docs currently, every > symbol in the examples has been encoded instead as &gt; instead, which obviously breaks those examples completely. Weirdly the < symbols are all fine though! See the code under http://lodash.com/docs#findLastIndex for an example.

Spent a little while looking at it, but I can't find the actual site codebase anywhere on github :confused:

title: Ensure _.xor() returns new unique array.
body: This ensures that `_.xor()` returns a new unique array regardless of the number of arrays it is given. Prior to this change passing one array like `_.xor([1, 1])` would return an unchanged reference.

title: Optimized compact method
body: Here is a relevant JSPerf link: http://jsperf.com/compact-optimization

title: oneToMany support in _.invert
_.zip.apply(null,[[1]])
body:
In version 1.2.1, this line

_.zip.apply(null,[[1]])

returns [[1]]

whereas in 2.4.1 it returns []

I believe the former is the correct behavior, what do you guys think?

title: Wouldn't it be more useful if `tap` transformed the list by using its return value?
body:
This occurred to me today while I was trying to do something that behaved as a `_.findOrCreate` which would attempt to find an item in a list, creating the item if the item doesn't exist.

```
_
.chain( [ ... ] )
.find({ key: value })
.tap(function (array) { if (!array) array = [{ ... }]; return array })
...
.value()
```

title: lodash.isEqual reports false in case where underscore.isEqual reports true
Sort order with multiple keys
body:
Hi, I am a in awe of the power of lodash. For my project it has been of invaluable help so far. However, now I am stuck with a problem with which lodash seems to fall a bit short.

Here is the problem:

I have an array of objects with the same properties, say 

```
[{name:"barney", age: 38},
 {name:"fred", age: 40},
 {name:"fred", age: 12}]
```

I want to sort the array by name in descending order, but age should be in ascending order. 

lodash supports multiple sorting keys by the "pluck" syntax, but only can deal with ascending sorting this way. Is there a way that the sortBy function is altered that it also accepts an array of objects that define the property name (key) and the order direction? I would love to do:

```
mySortedArr = _.sortby(
    unsortedArr, [
        {propertyName:"name", order:"desc"}, 
        {propertyName:"age", order:"asc"}
    ]);
```

Any chance something like that enters the library?

title: Add a Bitdeli Badge to README
body: Pull request made by @jdalton at https://bitdeli.com

title: Update README.md
body: examples are wrong.

title: _.partial(g, ...) alters g when g is a return from _.partial
body:
Here is a minimal example of the bad behavior. Same results in both Chrome and Firefox.

``` javascript
f = function (x, y) { return x + y; };
g = _.partial(f, 1);
g(4); // outputs 5
f(6, 7); // outputs 13
h = _.partial(g, 2);
g(4); // outputs 3
g(); // outputs 3
f(6, 7); // outputs 13
```

Notice that f is not affected while g is. I don't know the exact conditions for the first argument to partial to get affected; the above is the extent of my knowledge so far.

title: Optionally extend Array / Object prototypes with lodash functions
body:
While extending base types like Object and Array is generally a bad idea, being able to make lodash extend those types with the functions it provides could turn into a much more readable and chainable code, in controlled environments.

For example, string.js (http://stringjs.com) is a popular library that provides string utilities not found in String (trimming, padding...). It has a function (http://stringjs.com/#methods/extendprototype) that extends the String prototype, so that one can write the clearer

```
'Your name is JP'.right(2); 
```

instead of the default

```
S('Your name is JP').right(2).toString();
```

It would be great if lodash would do the same

``` javascript
_.extendPrototypes()
[1, [2], 2, 4].flatten().uniq();
_.restorePrototypes();
```

title: All Function depending on internal function "createWrapper" does not work how i would expect
Inconsistent behavior of _.first()
body:
Hey :)

It seems that `_.first([1, 2, 3]) => 1` (item) but `_.first([{ foo: 'bar' }]) => [ { foo: 'bar' } ]` (array of items)

This seems inconsistent to me, am I missing something?

body: I'd guess this won't be the final solution, but this worked out for my needs to control the wrapping behavior of mixed in functions.

title: add aliases to lodash-node
body:
the [readme](https://github.com/lodash/lodash-node#readme) for the [lodash-node](https://github.com/lodash/lodash-node) npm module indicates you can require all of lodash as a module, .e.g.

``` javascript
var _ = require('lodash-node');
```

or as a collection of methods by method category, e.g.

``` javascript
var collections = require('lodash-node/modern/collections');
```

However, it appears that collections of methods by method category do not include the aliases for that category, even though they are present in the root module for this npm package. For example,

``` javascript
var _ = require('lodash-node');
_.unique([1, 1, 0, 1]);
```

works fine, but 

``` javascript
var _ = require('lodash-node/modern/arrays')
_.unique([1, 1, 0, 1]);
```

results in

```
TypeError: Object #<Object> has no method 'unique'
```

Is this the intended behavior?

title: _.union difference between Lo-Dash and Underscore
body:
Hi. Both the `Lo-Dash` and `Underscore` docs seem to imply that `_.union` only takes `arrays` as parameters, but they both deal with non-array parameters very differently.

```
_.union('cat', ['dog'])
// Lo-Dash => ["dog"]
// Underscore => ["cat", "dog"]
```

`Lo-Dash` drops non-array parameters. It seems that you decided to this on purpose. From looking at `union()`, I noticed that `baseFlatten()` is called with `isStrict = true`. However, `Underscore's` decision isn't so clear. In their `union()`, their internal `flatten()` always pushes non-array items into the result `array`, but joins other `arrays` and `arguments` objects.

I don't really have an opinion on which why makes sense, just thought I'd point it out. Keep up the awesome work. I :heart: Lo-Dash.

title: inconsistent behavior with underscore on the _.first method
body: In underscore, `_.first([1,2,3], -1)` returns `[1,2]`. In lodash, it returns `[]`.

title: Broken use with Require.js shim (No longer exposing root._ in AMD)
Deactivate ES6 delimiter for _template() ?
body:
I'm using `yeoman` for templating a `build.xml` for `ant`. This file already uses a bunch of variables which have all the format `${...}`

Therefore I need to template the code `<% ...%>` in my `build.xml` but I also need to leave untouched the `${...}` in it, to not interfere with ant code

I could add a bunch of symbols to espace all `${...}` but it would complex the code

The quick and clean solution would be just to tell (dynamically) lodash to not support ES5, is it possible?

Thanks for your feedback

title: new _.entries -> _.pairs alias ?
body:
Hi.

It seems that Mozilla is ready to implement Array.prototype.entries() defined in recent ES6 specs :
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=894658

The behavior looks quite similar to the current to lodash _.pairs collection method.

So does it make sense to introduce a new _.entries alias pointing to _.pairs ?

Error in example for contains

```
     * _.contains('pebbles', 'ur');
     * // => true
```

Shouldn't that be `false`, tested in the console and it returns `false`

title: Utility methods for things other than Arrays and POJO?
body:
Neither underscore or lodash supports these, what is the consensus as to why? 

ES6 will support them but prior engines will not and it seems like a utility library _should_ have support for them. A small list off the top of my head for just `Strings` is:
- startsWith (_Arrays_ as well)
- endsWith (_Arrays_ as well)
- capitalize
- camelize
- humanize
- slugify
- repeat
- lines
- words
- groups (for regexp group matches)
- remove
- truncate
- toNumber

Maybe I am missing the overall message of lodash, or maybe it isn't conveyed well. Being a utility library all it does is provide some basic helper methods for Arrays and POJO in an attempt to be _faster_ than underscore but not providing any other benefit.

title: Single _.is[type] method
_.omit Performance Question
body:
Hi John-David,

I have encountered an issue with the _.omit function and wanted to get your thoughts.

I have a rather large array (~30000) of uuid strings to remove from a collection.

I run the collection through _.omit and get a "unresponsive script" warning in Firefox.

I can work around this, by changing to a `_.keys` -> `_.without` -> `_.object` combination - that then runs fine.

Is this just the performance difference between manipulating objects and arrays?

title: Fixed memory leak with debounce/throttle arguments and context
body:
Noticed that both underscore and lodash hold onto the arguments and context of the last execution of a debounced/throttled function. This leak can be serious (as is was in my app, retaining a giant DOM tree)

underscore just merged my PR for this https://github.com/jashkenas/underscore/pull/1329

lodash's implementation is quite a bit more complex so let me know if I missed a case. As discussed in the underscore PR, there isn't really a way to test this. (Unless you want me to resort to _.debounce.toString().replace + eval trickery to inject some local scoped tests?)

title: Adding syntactic sugar to reduce
Adding npm test command to package.json

title: Add a properties option to _.template
eachRight alias for forEachRight not in the minified builds
body:
At least in the compat and modern builds, the alias _.eachRight for _.forEachRight is not set, while other aliases are.

Looking at the minified source, it looks like the minifier is trying a bit too hard and minifies the eachRight property name: search for "y.q=It" in the current lodash.compat.min.js build, or for "Y.b=Nt" in the current lodash.min.js build.

title: Array-like consideration
body:
Would it be possible to consider array-like object (for instance jQuery-object, arguments etc.) like arrays in iterators like `forEach` and `map` to take profit from the optimisations made for arrays ? 

``` javascript
function isArrayLike(value){
  return value &&
    typeof value == "object" &&
    typeof value.length == "number" &&
    hasOwnProperty.call(value, "length") &&
    hasOwnProperty.call(value, value.length - 1)
}
```

title: zipObject support for default
body: It'd be nice if _.zipObject() supported a default value (besides an array of values) to be provided to all the created keys.

title: Enforce _.isArguments for legacy environments
body:
In the browsers that do not support the `[object Arguments]` class :

``` javascript
_.isArguments({length:0,callee:1})
// true
```

To ensure that this is a real arguments object, adding a test on `!Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable.call(value, "callee")` would prevent it as most (if not all) of these environment do not have a `Object.defineProperty`.

title: truey -> true
body: seems a typo, but I'm wondering because of the many occurrences.

title: Please consider adding _.noop method == empty function
body:
Hello,

Please consider adding noop function to the Lodash:

```
_.noop = function() {};
```

It would be identical to http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.noop/ with the same use cases.

The reason for this change is semantic one. I would like lodash to be truly my utility belt and leave all functional things to it leaving jQuery to work with the DOM only (and making AJAX requests :)). 

Thank you.

title: max() returning -Infinty when used with map()
chain().filter too permissive in underscore compact build
body:
In lodash's underscore compat build, the following

``` js
_.chain([]).filter().value()
```

returns an array

underscore, on the other hand, throws a Type Error. 

I stumbled on this by accident (I meant compact, but typed filter), but I assume that an error should be thrown in this situation since it is a compatibility build (even though lodash's output is obviously superior).

title: operations on a regex
body:
Maybe this isn't intended to be supported but did surprise me, maybe others.

```
_.each(/f(o)(o)/.exec('foo'), console.log)

TypeError: Object foo,o,o has no method 'each'
    at repl:1:7
    at REPLServer.replDefaults.eval (/usr/local/share/npm/lib/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/repl.js:33:28)
    at repl.js:239:12
    at Interface.<anonymous> (/usr/local/share/npm/lib/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/repl.js:62:9)
    at Interface.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:117:20)
    at Interface._onLine (readline.js:202:10)
    at Interface._line (readline.js:531:8)
    at Interface._ttyWrite (readline.js:760:14)
    at ReadStream.onkeypress (readline.js:99:10)
    at ReadStream.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:117:20)
```

I wonder if a special case should be made for regexp or we just know that it isn't supported and we do something like...

```
/f(o)(o)/.exec('foo').forEach(console.log)

foo 0 [ 'foo', 'o', 'o', index: 0, input: 'foo' ]
o 1 [ 'foo', 'o', 'o', index: 0, input: 'foo' ]
o 2 [ 'foo', 'o', 'o', index: 0, input: 'foo' ]
```

title: Automatic browser tests with SauceLabs in Travis
body:
This patch adds saucelabs support to lodash builds! See https://travis-ci.org/pimterry/lodash/jobs/13148270#L350 for an example result.

As set up here it's automatically running 3 builds, for some chosen firefox/chrome/IE versions, but this can be extended however you'd like by changing the platforms variable in the top of saucelabs.js.

**Note that this will not pass in lodash's travis build until saucelab credentials in .travis.yml are updated**. To do this, in .travis.yml you should update the SAUCE_USERNAME env var to an active saucelabs user account, and update the password by running `travis encrypt SAUCE_ACCESS_KEY=my-secret-sauce-access-key` and copying the output to replace the `secure: "KBETrs7...` line.

title: _.bindAll + comparator causes breakage on function-based Backbone methods
body:
Got caught on this today...

If you extend a `Backbone.Collection` with a `comparator` method and use `_.bindAll` within the initialize function, it blows up the comparator. This does not happen when using Underscore.

While I wasn't able to completely get down to the bottom of this, a key difference occurs in `Backbone.sort`, where `this.comparator` no longer has a length of 1 (as it does in Underscore.

Wish I could easily link to the Backbone source to help identify the discrepancy. Thought I'd identify it.

title: _.difference assumes arguments
Add `_.append` and `_.prepend`

As there is _.pull and _.remove to manipulate arrays, I thought it might be good idea to also offer functions to add new elements.

Use case with AngularJS/SocketIO

```
socket.on('list:init', _.partial(_.append, $scope.list)); // Multiple elements
socket.on('list:new', _.partial(_.append, $scope.list)); // Single element
```

TypeError: Cannot read property \"prototype\" from undefined (lodash.compat.js#501)

or for modern build

"TypeError: Cannot read property \"prototype\" from undefined (lodash2.2.1.js#462)"

Modern build 1.3.1 worked fine in this environment. 

I'll debug a bit but wanted to flag it as an issue.

title: Enhance `_.clone` and `_.cloneDeep`
body:
Let's enhance `_.clone` and `_.coneDeep`.
Currently `Date`s are not cloned by `_.clone` but they are cloned by `_.cloneDeep`. 
`Date` doesn't seem like a deep object and should probably be cloned by just a standard `_.clone`

Also, when using `_.cloneDeep` on a `RegExp`, the `lastIndex` property isn't copied.

title: Async/OO utility functions
body:
Since its possible to automate lodash builds with only used features, why not merge utilities like [async](https://github.com/caolan/async) and [klass](https://github.com/ded/klass) into lodash? 

Like lodash, those two libraries provide tools that polyfill missing language features and help solve common javascript problems so it would be nice to have everything one '_' away :)

title: Automatic feature detection
body:
I just wrote a small [module](https://github.com/tarruda/lodash-inspect) that automatically "guesses" lodash required features by inspecting a piece of javascript code.

I say "guesses" because its a very simple utility, all it does is parse the code and collect all method calls that matches any of lodash methods. While there's a lot of room for improvement, it should suffice for most use cases.

Perhaps you'd like to integrate something like this into lodash's main cli/grunt task? I guess a lot of people would like not having to maintain the list of dependencies manually.

title: _.random force float
body:
Some examples of the current _.random

``` javascript
_.random(10) // ints [0, 10]
_.random(10.1) // floats [0, 10.1]
_.random(10.0) // ints [0, 10]
```

Sometimes you want floats between 0 and 10, but that's currently impossible, other than doing these, which are close (they exclude 0 and 10 respectively):

``` javascript
_.random(Number.MIN_VALUE, 10) // closest positive number to zero, through 10

// or this where I had to do trial and error to find the 
// closest value to 10 that didn't round to 10
_.random(0, 9.999999999999998)
```

That doesn't work, if you want to get a float between 1 and 2, for example.  So, I propose a forceFloat (or similar name) as a third argument to random.

Changes required
- add the argument
- shift the arguments `if (max == null || max === false) { forceFloat = max; [...] }`
- change the float/int decision: `return (min % 1 || max % 1 || forceFloat) ?`

I estimate it'll add about 10 characters to the compiled JS (0.01kb before gzip).

If you're willing to add this, I can implement it and do a pull request, or you can.

The final examples then include:

``` javascript
_.random(0, 10, true) // floats [0, 10)
_.random(10, true) // floats [0, 10)
_.random(1, 2, true) // floats [1, 2)
_.random(1, 2) // 1 OR 2
```

title: New type checking in _.compose causes compose to fail when with called with no arguments
body:
In https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L5293 _.compose checks that all the arguments supplied are functions using `isFunction`. However, if _.compose is called with no arguments, it will fail

For example, this will fail:

``` javascript
_.compose();  // Throws TypeError, but succeeds in lodash v1.3.0 and underscore v1.4.4
```

**(Updated, sorry the issue is actually simpler than I originally explained)**

title: Plucked version _.min of returns unexpected Infinity result instead of undefined
body:
Using the "`_.pluck`" shorthand version of `_.min` on an empty array or an array that contains only `Infinity` values returns `Infinity`

I.e.

``` javascript
_.min([], "price")
=> Infinity              // expected (void 0)
_.min([{price: Infinity}, {price: Infinity}], "price")
=> Infinity             // expected {price: Infinity}
_.min([{price: 1}, {price: Infinity}], "price")
=> {price: 1}           // correct
```

This is due to the result being initialized as `Infinity` here: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L3709

It looks like `_.max` may have the same problem: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L3640

Thanks

title: Feature Request: pluck for embedded objects
Flattening a very large nested array fails (_.flatten)
body:
Using version: `2.0.0` 

This seems to fail in V8 (Chrome, Node etc.):

``` js
_.flatten([ Array(150000) ])
// throws:
// "Maximum call stack size exceeded"
```

This is due to the [following line](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/c7d6dbbdca3ddcf6e2061190bfe629631840fc6a/lodash.js#L1135):

``` js
push.apply(result, isShallow ? value : baseFlatten(value, isShallow, isArgArrays));
```

I.e. Using `Function#apply()` to pass a larger amount of arguments than are supported by the JS engine.

---

Curiously, it may work perfectly fine under other JS engines because each one seems to impose a different max-arg-length. So, while `150,000` is fine in Firefox, `550,000` fails:

``` js
_.flatten([ Array(550000) ])
// FF throws
// "RangeError: arguments array passed to Function.prototype.apply is too large"
```

Some rudimentary testing reveals the following _very rough_ argument max lengths:

(Exact numbers seem to depend on system resources at the time of testing. Test your browser here: http://jsbin.com/UrayIS/1)
- Opera 12 (_before V8_): ~1,000,000
- V8 (Chrome, Opera 13+, Node.js): ~125,000
- Firefox11-24: ~490,000
- Older Safari: Exactly 65536 (see https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=80797)

---

If it's considered worth fixing then I guess the best way would be to do some chunking into arrays of no more than `65536` and then pushing each chunk individually via `apply()`. Or, perhaps, feature-detecting the seemingly-arbitrary limits (which is quite costly).

title: setBindData has defined variable "noop"
body: https://github.com/lodash/lodash-node/blob/master/internals/setBindData.js#L32

title: Lodash Legacy not built in latest version
body: The latest build doesn't include legacy.legacy.min.js.  Although we can run a grunt operation to build it, it was very convenient to not worry about it.  thanks

title: each can not work with data which contains length key
body:
example coffee code:

coffee> _.forEach {a:1, length:1}, (v, k) -> console.log k, v
0 undefined
{ a: 1, length: 1 }

title: grunt-requirejs support
body:
I've just noticed this morning that our packages depending on [`grunt-requirejs`](https://github.com/asciidisco/grunt-requirejs) are failing to install.

After investigation, someone [rightfully points](https://github.com/asciidisco/grunt-requirejs/issues/73) that there has been a lot of changes in `lodash` and the `grunt-lodash` plugin recently. It also appears that rather unfortunately `grunt-lodashbuilder` (now deprecated but still used by `grunt-requirejs`) is using `latest` as its version of lodash.

What happened? Is there a way to get the 'original' 1.3.1 back so it can still be used?

title: _.at returns an array of 2 duplicate values
body: See [demo](http://codepen.io/Fresheyeball/pen/gErGi). If the second 2 arguments are the same, you get an array with 2 duplicate values instead of the expected result, an array of a single value.

title: lodash custom build: Closure Compiler and UglifyJS downloads fail
Adding _.repeat
body:
I came across a need for this in my work, so I figured I might as well share. This is my first time sending a PR so I'm sure I forgot to do something or did something wrong haha. I tried to follow the existing conventions.

Let me know if the documentation makes sense.

title: Improve JSDoc to allow better IDE integration
body:
To comply with JSDoc and IDE integration:
- `{Mixed}` should be `{*}`
- var_args should be `{...Type} [name]` instead of `{Type} [name, name, ...]`

Additionally, to avoid warnings (but this is not essential as the two above) :
- Parameter names cannot be things like `[name|other_name]`
- All primitive types should be lowercase, e.g. `{Number}` be `{number}`

Thank you :)

title: findIndex(Array) and findKey(Object) -> findKey(Collection)
body:
Often, I'll want to write code that leverages lodash's consolidated "Collection" API. However, several times, I've had to write switches on `_.isObject` so I could determine if I should use `_.findIndex` or `_.findKey`. Given than many of the Collection API functions already treat keys and indices transparently, wouldn't this be another one ripe for consolidation?

(Of course, whichever name "lost out" would still be available as an alias of the new function.)

title: support Regular Expressions for _.where et al
body:
For example http://lodash.com/docs#where could accept a regexp for `properties`.

The pattern would be matched
- For arrays, against the value (obvious)
- For objects, against the value (not obvious, how do we support keys?)

I have a use-case right now that equates to this:

```
_.reject(items, new RegExp(removeThing === 'all' ? '.*' : removeThing))
```
